please is the very important 

1 that this was a trend in the 1930s for people to build machines to model adaptive behavior. So Clark Hull was not the first by the one of the earliest and was among many who try to model.

And we can make a simple observation that, seems like Pavlov and Thorndike's lofty fact made it obvious for people to see that this is a way for people to build machines around these simple ideas which have powerful effects.

Second, he mentioned that they were already earlier attempts to model physiology in the early 1910s.

source.title: [R] [[KHElectro-Chemical31]] KruegerR, HullC - 1931 - An Electro-Chemical Parallel to the Conditioned Reflex.pdf
source.text:
APPARATUS 
AN ELECTRO-CHEMICAL PARALLEL T O  T H E  CONDITIONED 
REFLEX 
ROBERT G. KRUECER AND CLARK L. HULL’ 
The  past few months have witnessed the appearance of three distinct 
models designed to duplicate one phase or another of adaptive mammalian 
behavior (8, 14, 15, 1): A fourth investigator is approaching the problem 
from the point of view of mathematical physics (12). Apparently each of 
these projects was carried out entirely in ignorance of the others. While 
it is true that this is not the first time that a model intended to parallel 
adaptive behavior has been designed (13, l o ) ,  the practically simultaneous 
appearance of four or five independent efforts in this direction is not without 
significance as to the trend of the times. The present article contributes 
the description of still another model to this unique literature. 
It has been pointed out by Baernstein and Hull (1) that a polarizable 
cell manifests behavior strikingly similar to certain aspects of the condi- 
tioned reflex. T h e  present writers, utilizing this fact, have combined several 
such cells in a simple manner to form a purely electro-chemical model 
paralleling in still greater detail the behavior of the conditioned reflex. 
The wiring diagram of the model is shown in Figure 1. T h e  circles a t  E 
represent two dry cells. They are connected in series and furnish a po- 
tential of 3 volts. L, the responding mechanism, is a Zg-volt flashlight bulb 
connected in series with the battery, E. S,,, which represents the uncon- 
ditioned stimulus, is a single-pole push button which completes the uncon- 
ditioned stimulus circuit. T h e  circuits containing the neutral stimuli to be 
conditioned consist of the radio “B” storage cells, El, Et, Es, El, and ES 
connected in parallel with the light. S1, S,, St, S,, and SS are single-pole 
push buttons placed in series with the corresponding storage cells and con- 
necting each with the responding bulb. Resistances of from 80 to 120 
ohms, RI, Ra, R,, and R,, connect the positive plate of each cell to the positive 
plate of the adjacent cells. 
THE UNCONDITIONED REACTION 
If S,, alone is pressed, current from battery E will pass through the 
filament of L causing it to become luminous. This represents the uncondi- 
‘The model was designed and constructed by the first author. T h e  basic 
psychological ideas and the formulation of the results are due to the second. 
‘A fifth independent attempt has come to our attention through personal 
correspondence. 
262

source.title: [R] [[CorDiscovery02]] CordeschiR - 2002 - The Discovery of the Artificial - Behavior, Mind and Machines Before and Beyond Cybernetics.pdf
source.text:
104 CHAPTER 3 
tive stimulation, which Hull called "goal stimulus" and designated s0 (Hull, 1931 ). It is 
a constant accompaniment to the course of action no less than S0 and is the authentic dy­
namic mechanism that makes the organism "hormic or purposive," as Hull was later to 
express it (Hull, 1942: 90). 14 
What he thought he found in the anticipatory goal reaction that aroused stimulus s0 
was a physical mechanism that could account for the so-called "paradox of backward cau­
sation," which seemed typical of anticipatory action in purposive behavior. The paradox 
lay in the traditional difficulty of explaining how an idea, by definition mental and non­
physical, could cause a physical action and how the idea, while representing the purpose 
or future end to which the action was directed, could cause an action working backward 
and thus guiding the subsequent course of the action. Consider the following: "I am read­
ing and it grows dark. I think of turning on the electric light, and without hesitation that 
action is performed. The act here described is just as purposive as ifl had deliberated and 
planned out every step in the procedure beforehand." 15 It is like witnessing a veritable 
inversion of the causal order: the future result of an act precedes the act itself in the chain 
of causation. Hence the appeal to the 'final cause' of traditional teleology, which sup­
ported a teleological explanation as opposed to a causal one. 
In the next chapter we shall see that this paradox gave rise to several attempts to rec­
oncile the teleological and causal explanations until the solution hypothesized at the ad­
vent of cybernetics. To stay with Hull, he attacked vitalist thinkers and what he called 
psychologists "dominated by metaphysical idealism," for whom the paradox could be re­
solved only by appeal to the non-physical principle of fmal causes. The principle of an­
ticipatory goal reaction suggested a different solution to Hull. Anticipatory goal reaction 
did not have an instrumental function but a symbolic one, because its sole function was 
to produce a goal stimulus, which precedes the goal. So the anticipatory goal reaction 
plays the role traditionally ascribed to the ideas of guiding and controlling the sequence 
of acts of purposeful behavior. Yet it is a physical mechanism, since it consists of an ac­
tion that was also a stimulus to action, so its effect, like its origin (produced by S0 ), was 
physical and not mental in the sense of metaphysical psychology (Hull, 1931: 502-506). 
But for Hull anticipatory goal reaction was not the sole physical mechanism to play 
a causal role in the cognitive activity of higher organisms (the role played by "what in 
the past have been called ideas"). Indeed, in the case of human beings he granted that it 
might be necessary to add several other principles. His theoretical and experimental work 
alike seemed to confirm the automatic nature of more complex forms of anticipatory be-
"Hull's choice of terms is significant, recause the use of 'hormic' as a synonym for 'purposeful' was made 
popular by McDougall (1923a: 72), though in order to stress the irreducibility of purpose to any mechanistic ex­
planation. But Hull made a point of identifying purpose with the goal stimulus s0 and not with the drive stimulus 
S0 , which we saw as the source of a different and more elementary kind of anticipatory rehavior (see section 2 
above). Mediational hypothetical constructs connected with anticipatory goal response were held in high esteem 
by Hull's followers, such as Hobart Mowrer and C. E. Osgood (see especially Mowrer, 1960a, 1960b). Grossrerg 
(1982) discussed several difficulties concerning anticipatory goal reaction. See also Chapter 6, section 4. 
"The example comes from Howard Warren, "A Study of Purpose" (Warren, 1916: 8), an essay that will re 
discussed in the next chapter.
